awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Research in Physics at the University of Arkansas
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The Physics research experience for undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Arkansas continues to provide exciting research opportunities to students, mostly from, but not limited to, undergraduate institutions in the Ozark region and surrounding states with limited or no infrastructure to support undergraduate research. Each year, a diverse group of students including women and underrepresented minorities are targeted for recruiting. The success with this aspect is assured by a network of faculty and alumni contacts at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) and institutions with significant Native American and Hispanic populations, and the University's infrastructure for minority recruiting. Additionally, a few students who may have not performed well in courses, but show indication of originality and creativity, are included. The selected students participate in experimental and theoretical research projects in nanoscale materials, condensed matter, soft matter, biophysics, photonics, lasers, and quantum optics. They acquire skills and practices essential to scientific problem solving and for working in a collaborative environment through mentoring from faculty, post-doctoral scholars, and senior graduate students. They visit high-tech industries, participate in professional development activities that include weekly seminars, workshops on laboratory safety, library database searches, graduate school applications, oral and written communications skills, a participatory scientific ethics course, and social/cultural activities with other REU groups. The evaluation process incorporates both direct measures of student success and indirect measures (student, mentor, alumni survey) of learning and achievements to provide guidance to continually upgrade the REU program and broaden its impact. Many participants in the REU site continue with graduate studies or find employment directly after graduation in a science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) fields.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The REU participants work on carefully chosen research projects on topics of current interest such as properties of nanoscale materials, thermal motion of free standing grapheme using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), atomically thin material quantum devices, solid-state nanopore fabrication for detection of DNA, phase transition in two dimensional atomic materials beyond graphene, light-quantum dot interaction, lasers, structured light beams, quantum correlations in light, super-resolution fluorescence microscopy, and statistical and nonlinear physics of extremophiles and the brain. Through engagement with their research projects for ten weeks, the participants receive technical training in using the state of the art instruments, and computational and analytical research techniques. They experience the creative process involved in scientific research starting from the formulation of a problem to its solution, the ups and downs, and the eventual thrill of a new discovery. At the end of the summer, students present their research at a REU symposium. Many go on to present the results of their research at national/international scientific conferences and publish papers based on their work in scientific research journals. Each REU participant leaves having acquired technical skills in the use of advanced scientific instruments and softer skills to be a productive member of the nation's scientific and technical workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
UA Physics REU 2019- 2022 outcome

The University of Arkansas Physics REU site provided 10-week summer research experience in experimental and theoretical projects in biophysics, computational condensed matter physics, nanomaterials, lasers, quantum optics, nonlinear optics, and photonics. Each participant worked on a cutting-edge research project with an experienced faculty mentor and, depending on the research projects, acquired experimental, theoretical, and computational problem-solving skills from their faculty mentors and/or members of their research group. These included planning a research project, literature search, data acquisition and analysis, writing a research paper, and presenting their research. They learned how to design laser cavities and align optics, how to make nano-devices, synthesize single crystals and two-dimensional materials with exotic properties and how to characterize them, operate a scanning tunneling microscope, confocal microscopes, super-computer programing, prepare, handle, and analyze biological samples, DNA sequencing, learn how brain encodes sensory inputs, etc. 

In addition to working on their research projects, the students participated in professional development activities. Weekly research seminars/lab tours by the physics faculty exposed the students to other research areas. The students also attended workshops dealing with graduate school application process, writing scientific papers, preparing conference presentations, machine shop classes and electronics classes. An interactive and participatory ethics class, with Material Science and Engineering program, provided the opportunity for them to improve their communication skills. Dallas field trip to Globitech, Zyvex, and Texas Instruments RFAB facility gave the exposure to high-tech industrial manufacturing, research and development, and internships and career opportunities in these sectors. 

A number of other enrichment activities, common to all REUs on campus, were also organized. All REUs had the same start date and housed their interns in the same dorm. This expanded the academic and cultural diversity of an already diverse group by bringing people of different backgrounds together. Interaction with this group broadened the students? outlook increasing their awareness and understanding of the diversity of our nation promoting social cohesiveness. 

During the three summers (2019, 2021, 2022), a total of 34 students, all from other institutions (27 schools in 15 states) participated in the program. 88% of the students came from schools without a physics PhD program, 79% from schools with limited or no infrastructure to support research, 65% came from Arkansas and neighboring states. The program was successful in recruiting from its target populations that included females and under-represented minority (URM) groups from undergraduate institutions in the Ozark region.  Nearly half (47%) were women [much higher than the national average of 23%], 19% [compared to the national average of 10%] were from URM. 

Despite their varied academic backgrounds, all the students were able to complete their REU projects with enthusiasm for scientific research and gained confidence in their abilities to succeed in a Ph.D. program. At the end of the REU, each student submitted a research paper based on their findings and presented their work in a conference-style setting. The students thus left with slides for an oral presentation at their home institutions, with the potential to inspire another group of undergraduates to participate in research. Of 2019-22 cohorts, 26 (76%) have completed their BS degree out of which 8 (31%) have joined the UA graduate program. The remaining 8 are on track to graduating.  Participants from the REU 2015-2022 cohort have presented 50 papers at national, international, or regional conferences and coauthored 26 publications (with a few still in preparation). This is a remarkable achievement considering that most students came with little or no research experience. 

The outcome of many projects also helped in strengthening research of the participating faculty mentors. For graduate students, this was a professional development opportunity to act as mentors, a role many will be expected to fulfill either as faculty members or scientists in industry. Interaction with graduate students helped REU students, especially from undergraduate institutions, visualize themselves as graduate students.
